awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Virtual Assessment of Foot and Gait for Smartphone-Enabled Personalized Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve modeling and treatment for various disorders. The initial application is to personalize footwear.  This project uses a smartphone camera to determine the size and orientation of feet and gait.  It combines computer vision, image processing, machine learning, material science, and anatomy and physiology to develop a virtual solution to fit shoes. This enables a new low-cost method for evaluating physiological conditions with potentially straightforward consumer solutions.  

This project supports a novel data-analytics solution that provides accurate footwear recommendations based on static foot shape and dynamic foot function, using only a smartphone to capture images.  This project will develop the algorithms using machine learning and statistical modeling for a user to evaluate the potential utility of a comfortable shoe. This project will evaluate the prediction accuracy of a prototype system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this NSF SBIR Phase 1 project were to develop a smartphone machine learning (ML)-based foot measurement system and to design a personalized precision-fitted sneaker by automating custom shoemaking. These objectives drive innovation across various aspects of shoe fit: selection of subjective assessments required for fit, use of automation in fit, scalable custom manufacturing, and feedback system to hone the design. The shoe custom fit solution proposed by Iambic spans 12 innovations broadly divided among the automation and streamlined manufacturing of personalized shoes. The AI-driven automation allows innovation on 3 fronts: i) foot measurements and shape obtained using a smartphone camera without the need for an in-person consultation session; ii) design consideration based on user-specific foot and shoe construction preferences; and iii) inclusion of the art driving the shoe silhouette. The combination of these 3 factors governs the shape of the shoe last which is essential for shoe manufacturing and overcomes the bottleneck in traditional handmade custom shoe manufacturing.

Iambic undertook a rigorous foot and footwear data collection effort as part of this study. The aim of data collection was to establish a comprehensive and representative dataset for ML training and other predictive algorithms that includes all demographic groups across genders, ethnicities/races, and age groups. This is critical for the ML models to accurately determine foot measurements on any user?s feet images. Generally, the foot image datasets generated by other entities are limited in at least one of several aspects: gender balance, ethnic and racial diversity, age group coverage, contextual data on foot health and footwear issues, and user preference for footwear construction. Our datasets addressed these issues in the data collection and the resulting trained ML models performed with good accuracy on diverse user images to obtain their foot measurements.

Iambic set up a custom sneaker system that incorporates AI-driven foot measurements, personal foot and footwear preferences, and feedback from the user to design and continuously improve the custom sneaker. Traditionally, the process of making a custom shoe is a slow, manual process that can take weeks to months with the shoe last as the primary bottleneck. The shoe last is the mold that drives the shoe shape and size and must be millimeter level precise for a custom shoe. We identified primary locations of shoe last modification that can be automated; thus, reducing the time and process to modify the last based on an individual?s foot shape and measurements while retaining the last and shoe silhouette for a stylish shoe. The custom sneaker is further intended to be perfected through the wearer?s feedback which is essential for fine-tuning the custom shoe for the user over time and keeps in the loop any changes to the foot shape and health of the user. A survey-based approach was applied to receive feedback from the shoe wearer on the wearer-centric aspects of the shoe. Overall, the shoe testers showed a positive response towards the Iambic sneaker wear, particularly on durability, material, and comfortability.

Iambic's data-driven, on-demand manufacturing model is a critical aspect of our strategy to improve footwear fit, thereby contributing to the promotion of public health and well-being. This approach also supports environmental sustainability through the efficient utilization of resources. Existing solutions to the problem of custom fit are incomplete (custom insoles), unfashionable (stretchable uppers), expensive (traditional handbuilt custom fit), or unscalable (3D printing). These limitations keep custom fit shoes out of reach for a large segment of society, thereby contributing to the health issues driven by poor fit that are prevalent today. Our automation of the custom-fit process that tackles the entire 3D geometry of the foot and shoe has the potential to drastically reduce costs to consumers by 1/10th of those of traditional custom-fit shoes. Combining on-demand with made-to-fit manufacturing allows Iambic to provide customers with shoes that are tailored to their specific needs, resulting in increased customer satisfaction alongside decreased over-production and inventory waste.

In summation, Iambic completed a comprehensive data collection, ML training and validation, shoe last development and personalized modification, custom shoe manufacturing, shoe wear test, and biomechanical test as part of this study. We established the feasibility of our methodology and the success of our technology platform, built industry relationships for further product development, and connected with prospective customers to create traction for the technology and product. For the custom shoe-making industry specifically and the shoe industry at large, our technology allows for faster shoe design, modification, and sizing, as required by the supply chain.
